post.heading: Prior Art Relevant to Patent US 11230032
post.p: The patent in question was filed on Apr 13, 2018. We will refer to the patented contraption as SkyBAAM, or "the patented contraption", for short. We will present prior art relevant to SkyBAAM, all of which was unmentioned and unreferenced in the patent. The prior art we present will mostly have been published within context of the open source project called Hangprinter.
The patent contains many ideas that have been explored, published, and then discontinued within the Hangprinter community before Apr 13, 2018.

This writing will be long and detailed. The corpus of relevant prior art published publicly before April 13 2018 is vast, since the Hangprinter Project was already four years old at the time. This prior art includes, but is not limited to:
56 technical blog posts
Ca 350 posts on Reprap forums
thread 1
thread 2
thread 3
A few hundred posts in the Facebook group
Ca 25 relevant Youtube videos
37 videos published on Vimeo
Ca 100 Tweets
13 Hangprinter Newsletters
Wiki articles on Appropedia, Open Source Ecology and Reprap Wiki.
The hangprinter.org landing page
A public Github repo containing over 500 relevant commits and issues
A number of news articles, including but not limited to these
hackaday.com
hackaday.com again
3dprintingindustry.com
seeker.com
sciencedaily.com
fabbaloo.com
wired.com
3dprint.com
Note that all links in this post goes to previous art that was published publicly before April 13, 2018.

The patent made two references to Hangprinter:
The English Wikipedia Article, who was mostly just a list of links at the time
An out of date article from 3ders.org

Those two sources alone do not cover enough details to reveal how deeply similar SkyBAAM is to the pre-existing Hangprinter. I will therefore present a selection of prior art here, picked from the long list above.

I will comment on prior art that covers the highest level, most general ideas presented in the patent first, and slowly zoom in on technical details and implementation. However, some similarities are striking even at a long distance, without reference to technicalities, so I will cover those first.
The Hangprinter prototype that was most visually similar to Fig 4 in the patent might be this early version 3 prototype, that was published and described in detail on April 4, 2017.

figure.figcaption: The video shows the first Hangprinter prototype that offloaded the motors and most of the electronics to one of the anchors.
Fig 4 from from the patent in question.
Fig 5 from from the patent in question.

post.p: What we see here is of course a very general machine. The fewer the lines in the sketch, the more general the machine. Like futuristic art, you fill in the rest with your fantasy.

Formulations like the following make it sound like the patent covers the field of translational parallel cable driven robotics in its entirety:
"[...] an outdoor work site. Smaller-scale and/or indoor implementation are also contemplated"
"one or more additional base stations"
"one or more additional adjustable cables may be associated with any of the base stations"
" the base stations 22A, 22B, 22C can include at least one pulley 42, multiple pulleys, or another suitable cable guide which route the cables 28A, 28B, 28C to change the direction of the force applied by the cables"
"The various cables can be wound around their associated cable winders for transportation to a worksite"

The rest of us will have to continue our research on machines with three or less base stations, and cables that can't be wound around their associated cable winders for transportation, then. Or maybe it helps us to show that Hangprinter used between four and six lines in each direction already on July 5, 2017?

figure.figcaption: Video published August 1, 2017, demonstrating how additional lines in all directions help constrain rotational degrees of freedom, and I guess also its ability to "wind in its lines for transportation".

post.p: Oh well, maybe all previous public plans to add more anchors to Hangprinter must be scrapped? Or maybe it helps us that many translational parallel cable driven robots already had more than four anchor a long time before 13 Apr, 2018?
You never know. Let's stay nervous that something in this patent might still be valid, just to be on the safe side.
Luckily, the patent later narrows itself down by specifying some things:
"FIG 4. [...] three adjustable suspension cables 30 run from the aerial hoist 18 to the end effector 20, and perform the z-axis motion"
Since "the fixed platform 34" is stationary, the formulation "z-axis motion" indicates that the end effector 20 can only move along a straight vertical line line. Like this:

figure.figcaption: Hangprinter version 3, assembly file as it looked in the Hangprinter repo on Apr 10, 2018. We were unaware at the time, that our machine, even in this stripped down form, could deserve a patent.

post.p: Oh well, that suddenly made the patent very narrow, bordering on the unexpected. Let's help the patent authors by assuming they made a mistake.

After all, Fig 4 is only "another embodiment of a cable configuration for the cable-driven additive manufacturing system". So let's look closer for details that differentiates it from for example a Hangprinter.

"One difference is that three adjustable suspension cables 30 run from the aerial hoist 18 to the end effector 20 [...] all run off one cable winder 32 [...] so that their length is always identical."
I think they mean like this:

figure.figcaption: Video published Dec 8, 2016, demonstrating a worm drive on the D-axis on-board cable rewinder. We were unaware at the time that having three lines around a single spool could constitute an invention, so we didn't mention it, but it's clearly visible. The "cable rewinder" is onboard the end effector. The "aerial hoist" is shown, in the form of free hanging bearings, at the start of the video.

post.p:
"This keeps the end effector 20 from tilting, which freezes two rotational DOF of the end effector 20."
I'm unsure what is meant by "freezing", since degrees of freedom are independent of degrees of temperature. Ok, let's assume they made a mistake again. They surely meant "constrains two rotational DOF", right? Like this:

figure.figcaption: Image of Hangprinter version 2 published on my blog on 14 Dec, 2016.

post.p: However, even if they meant "constrained", they would still be in error. Those rotational degrees of freedom are not constrained in either of their Figs 4 and 5. That's because they again narrow the scope of their patent by specifying that all cables, and hence anchors are in the x-y plane, like this:
"... freezes all the rotational DOF [...]. First, by putting more cables in the x-y plane, the stiffness of the system 14 is increased in the x-y plane."
Oh gosh, with the top anchor only involved in z-axis movements, and all other cables in a flat plane, we're left with an end effector that's fixed in a single point, unable to move at all.

It's peculiar how the patent's authors insist on keeping both lines and anchors in "the x-y plane". This will leave rotations around the x-axis and the y-axis unconstrained, since the "z-lines" can only pull upwards, and not push downwards.

Even if the end effector is pulled in four directions at once, it's not being pulled downwards at all. The extrusion of material below it will eventually build up and push it upwards. This will cause rotation. The situation will look similar to this, but with concrete:

figure.figcaption: This image is not previous art. It was published too late, on Oct 21, 2019.

post.p: I'm trying to assume that they're honestly trying to describe normal translational 3d movements, like other translational cable driven parallel robots do, but the patent's authors don't make it easy for me:
"From the pulleys 42U, 42M, and 42L to the end effector, the cables 28U, 28L can run generally orthogonally to the support surface 60."
The number 60 they're talking about, is the front plate of this thing:

figure.figcaption: Fig 7 from from the patent in question.

post.p: So, if the cables 28U and 28L are orthogonal to the front plate 60, then the end effector can only move along a line that is parallel to plate 60's normal direction. With three different normal directions, this again constrains the end effector to stay put at a single point in space.
In reality, the lines 28U and 28L will not stay orthogonal to 60, not even close, not even "generally".
Let's assume the patent's authors made another mistake.
Oh wait, by the way, doesn't that thing look eerly similar to that old Hangprinter 3 prototype 1 anchor?

figure.figcaption: Two happy anchors waiting for the third one to be produced. This is screenshot from the video at the top of this post, who shows how they're used.

post.p: Never mind, they get back on track, by specifying:
"In one embodiment, at least a portion of the base station 22 can telescope to raise the pulleys 42U, 42M, and 42L."
So we're back up to one embodiement of their patented contraption that can carry out linear vertical motions, by utilizing a total of at least 7 motors.
The telescopes are supposed to act like linear vertical axes, that can lift the pivot points of the lower lines. Kind of like this:

figure.figcaption: A small Hangprinter version 3, published by Antonio Baez in the Facebook group on Dec 18, 2017. We see the lower lines being lifted by black v-shaped bearings, attached to yellow carriages that travel along linear rails. The yellow carriages seem to not be motorized in "this embodiment of" Hangprinter version 3. In another embodiment, it actually uses its highest motor to lift the other ones if needed. Never seen in reality though.

post.p: While we're on the topic of number of motors. They suggest increasing the number to at least 8 or 10, like this:
"The base station 22 can optionally include a cable winder 50 for a suspension cable 30 used to adjust the position of an aerial hoist 18 (FIG. 8)."
I feel like we're increasing the scope of this patent again. Let's look at FIG. 8 and FIG. 2.

figure.figcaption: Fig 2 from from the patent in question. The "aerial hoist" is number 18.
Fig 8 from from the patent in question.

post.p: So, the "aerial hoist" does the same job as the v-shaped bearings in this image, from a previously presented video:

figure.figcaption: The "aerial hoist" of Hangprinter verision 2. The cable rewinder is situated on the end effector itself.

post.p: However, the "aerial hoist" in the Fig 8 redirects the line towards an anchor ("base station"), so that all motors can potentially be located at ground level, like this:

figure.figcaption: A Hangprinter with the "ceiling unit" placed on the floor, published by Antonio Baez in the Facebook group on Nov 29, 2017. Baez mainly uses lamp hooks to reroute the lines.

post.p: But there's one last peculiar thing about Fig 8. It includes springs (74) between the top hook and the cables.

Introducing springs here and there to keep lines tight is a common beginner's mistake when designing Hangprinters, because it reduces positional control, limits maximum speeds and accelerations, and introduces eigenfrequencies in the motion system. It has been discussed many times, but never introduced into Hangprinter.
However, earlier open source translational cable driven parallel robots did use springs, like for example this one:

figure.figcaption: Brandon Heller's Youtube video from 2013 predates Hangprinter. Like most cable driven translation robots, Hangprinter included, it uses pairs of cables that are "generally parallel to each other" as it's formulated in the patent. It also uses rubber bands to pull upwards in much the same way as the patented contraption uses its springs.

post.p: But I have another problem with Fig 2. It's overly ambitious idea of 3d printing the Colluseum is just so darn similar to my own 2017 Babel tower project:

figure.figcaption: This image was published in a blog post on 24 Feb, 2017.
Fig 2 from from the patent in question.

The video shows how the 3d animation covering hangprinter.org's front page for a full year before the patent in question was filed. hangprinter.org was launched on Apr 4, 2017, and the animation was there until it was replaced on 21 Sep, 2020.

post.p: The artistic expression (as well as the physical implementation), of an unfinished circular tower with tall arched windows, and a thick helical structure along the outer wall, being 3d printed by a cable driven parallel robot with four cable-directions, one of which is near vertical, driving an effector with rotational degrees of freedom being constrained by pairs of generally parallel cables, of which anchors (called base stations in the patent) are potentially lifted above ground level with thin tall structures, was published widely on all 3d printing news sites in Feb/March 2017, a year before the patent was filed.

Images of this Babel tower were published on every 3d printingn news site in March 2017, including but not limited to:
fabbaloo.com
3dnatives.com
archdaily.com
3dprintingindustry.com
3dprint.com
post.h2: But How About Houses, Scaling Up, Using Concrete, Using A Crane?
post.p: Just to be clear, the history of the Babel tower in the Holy Bible does not describe a 40 x 40 cm tower that was 4.6 m tall. The printed Babel tower on the images above is a scaled down version of the Babel tower I had in mind. The idea of scaling up a small Babel tower is not an invention in my humble opinion.

The idea of printing with cement appeared already on the first page of the first forum thread about Hangprinter back in 2014, and has kept appearing at a rate of every fiftieth forum post or so suggesting it. My reply was that beefing up the parts should be straightforward.
Scaling up is among the first two benefits I mention in the very first blog post about Hangprinter, from May 15, 2014.

Apart from being very obvious, the general idea of "3d printing houses with Hangprinters, out of concrete, while hanging from cranes" was frequently discussed in public around 2017 and 2018. One of the more entertaining conversations included these visuals.

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. Screenshot from the Facebook group called "Hangprinter - RepRap Project " on March 17, 2018. A person called Ed Aylward posted visuals, related to the common idea of scaling up Hangprinter for printing concrete buildings, in the Facebook group, stating patent pending on the idea. The idea of "crane with wheels" is discussed in the conversation.

post.p: The group had over 200 members and increasing, already a year earlier. This was a big public group with very active discussion about Hangprinter.

The web page that Mr Aylward linked to in his post was saved by Wayback Machine on 28 Feb, 2018, so he had clearly created it at least a few days before posting publicly. At the time of writing this, the web page is still up.

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. An illustration of the frequent and common idea of 3d printing a concrete house with Hangprinter, screendumped from Aylward's publicly linked web site.

post.p:
It was, for the longest time unclear whether the "invention" in these visuals was to
Scale up a toy, or to
scale down the idea of a crane.
Luckily, Mr Aylward included an object of known size in his 3d visualization:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. Aylward's web page displays 3d graphics, and lets us zoom in on the displayed object. We can see that this is Hangprinter version 1, and not version 2, because it does not yet use a worm gear for its D-axis (mostly vertical axis), like the Hangprinter version 2 did. If we search through Github's catalouge, we can probably pin down when it was downloaded because it includes a distinct bug: there are two motors with "B-gears", both driving the "B-lines" in the render. That bug would make the machine not work as intended in practice, and was probably removed soon after, in the real Hangprinter repo. The three low anchors are also identical to those published as Hangprinter version 1 anchors in the Hangprinter repo.

post.p: This would imply that the "invention" was a combination of the two above. A very large toy truck pushing a cylinder down through a standard Hangprinter via a very small crane.
No, of course I understand that the cylinder would contain un-cured concrete, and the very large Hangprinter would be printing a concrete shell for a house.
post.h2: But The Super Smart Tension Control Described In the Patent, How About That?
post.p: I assume they mean torque control, as it's called in Hangprinter circles? All Hangprinter anchors have tension control.

figure.figcaption: Video published August 1, 2017. Since torque mode (tension control) only controls the torque of the motors (and hence the tension of the cables), the en effector will move if you drag it by hand.

post.p: Torque mode is a standard feature since 2017. It's very practical when you start the printer up and want to move the end effector safely and rapidly without thinking too much.

It's also used during auto-calibration (automatic anchor localization within the xyz coordinate system). During auto calibration it's common for a Hangprinter to mix the normal "position mode" with torque mode, frequently switching modes for individual motors.

An advanced non-linear minimization algorith is applied to transform the set of collected quadruples of motor positions, into a set of four anchor locations. The version of the algorithm that was available on Apr 13, 2018 can be found here: auto-calibration-simulation-for-hangprinter.
post.h2: But SkyBAAM Has Its Cable Rewinders At The Base Stations! Hangprinter Does Not
post.p: This is another discussion that has kept coming back at a rate of ca one out of fifty forum posts. The following one is from Feb 2017:

ul.li: MechaBits: "Was there a reason you never went with the motors on the walls?"
tobben: "Yup several reasons, of course. One of them is that I have to tidy up after me each time I've used the printer. [part of quote left out for brevity] ..."
MechaBits: "But surely you could also do that with motors on the walls."
tobben: "Quite possible, of course. I'd love to see such a solution."
MechaBits: "I would have thought you where in a better position to mentally picture what it would look like, due to your experience with this."

tobben: "Oh yes, you would have to choose between synchronizing steppers wirelessly, drive them from a stationary PCB or to find a smart way to wind stepper cables.
Last alternative first: You could carry the stepper drivers and the microcontroller on the moving part. Signal noise because of the stepper cable lengths would be no (or a very small) problem, but they will of course have weight. You could wind in the motors when not in use and park everything in the ceiling. Nice.
Wireless motor control is probably the best solution for very big high-performance machines. You must do more programming, need more PCBs and more power supplies. The PCBs could be placed almost anywhere and you don't need to hide a lot of ugly cables. Semi nice.
With one stationary PCB and long cables to stationary motors, it will be a lot of work to make it look tidy. You will have to transform your entire room into a RepRap frame. If quick and dirty solutions, like cables taped to the floor/ceiling, works for you, and if you never need your room for something else, then this solution gives you the most print performance for your time and your buck. Or at least, that's my guess."

post.p: In my humble opinion, moving the motors to the anchors is a very obvious thing to do for anyone wanting to scale up Hangprinter. For example Open Source Ecology had this on their Hangprinter wiki page already on 17 Dec, 2017:

Open Source Ecology seemed to think that Hangprinter was already being used for 3d printing of buildings. They also knew that "Keep Motors on the anchor stations" was a prerequisite for a minimal viable product.

Note that Open Source Ecology, and all the others that suggested locating the motors at the various anchor points back in 2017 and early 2018, in all the links are laymen trying to help out, not even having "ordinary skill in the art" of cable driven robotics. That's how obvious these ideas are.

The patent in question describes guy wires going from the D-anchor (high-up) anchor down to the anchors (base stations) with tension in them to pull the D-anchor downwards and outwards, and hence stabilizing it. See for example lines 36 in Fig 4 from their patent, near the top of this web page.

We have never used the terms "guy-wire" or "suspension wire" much in the Hangprinter community. However, we've had lines going between the D-anchor and the lower anchors, just like guy wires would, since April 2017. See for example the video posted at the top of this article, or this image that was published on Dec 7, 2017:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. Hangprinter version 3 being demonstrated on Maker Fair Rome in December 2017. Lines pulling the D-anchor down towards all three low anchors, with fixated start points and end points, are visible in the image against the white background.
This render was uploaded on Feb 9, 2018, by Nick Scott, to the public Hangprinter group on Facebook.

post.p: Although Hangprinter's guy wires are rerouted to also serve as transmitting motion forces to the end effector, these lines double up to do the same guy-wire pulling as the static cables mentioned in the patent would do, as long as all the lines are always tight, which they always are since the machine would otherwise loose control over the effectors translational movement.

Some might believe that the SkyBAAM's guy wires would have a constant tension in them, but in fact they would not have constant tension. The tension in the SkyBAAM's guy wires would vary greatly depending on variation in the pulling force from above, and depending on where within the build volume (called W in the patent) were at any given time, because the end effector is connected to the D-anchor (highest anchor), where the guy wires are also connected. Therefore, the conceptual difference between the SkyBAAM's guy wires and Hangprinter's guy wires is only superficial if at all.
So even though it might look like Hangprinter doesn't need guy wires, it does have them, as part of a dual purpose line routing configuration.
post.h2: But The UHMWPE Wires Then? Does Hangprinter Have Them?
post.p: Yes. Hangprinter has never used anything else. See for example this Bill Of Materials List from Dec 9, 2015.
Ok, so we've been having some fun. However, the similarities between the patented contraption and Hangprinter are not merely superficial. We can dive deeper, and ask questions like:
post.h2: But Was The Repo Publicly Available?
post.p: The general public had access and usage rights to the repo continously at all times since Dec 15, 2014, including on Apr 13, 2018.

Information about how popular and well known the repo was on Apr 13, 2018 can be found by using archive.org, also known as Wayback Machine. It is a service that stores and archives old web pages, so we can visit them again, and see exactly how they looked on given dates, superficially similar to how the git/Github saving and catalouging works. However, it does not save every web page every day, so the investigated dates will precede Apr 13, 2018 by weeks or months.
This is how github.com/tobbelobb/hangprinter looked on Jun 26, 2017:

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version.

post.p: In the image we can see that the repo had 77 watchers, 248 stars, and 49 forks. This means that this was a popular repo at the time. The 49 forks means that at least 49 people have copied Hangprinter's source files to use as the basis for their own cable driven robot build.
The license in the repo allows and encourages such copying. Hangprinter was the most popular and widely known basis for cable driven robot development in 2017 and 2018.

Although the patent doesn't mention kinematics transforms in detail, I will mention Hangprinter's briefly here, to make the case that Hangprinter was capable of doing a superset of the effector movements that the authors envision in the patent.

figure.figcaption: Click the image for a larger version. We see here that Hangprinter calculates its desired line lenghts by using Pythagoras' theorem on all its four cable directions.

post.p: The anchors can therefore be placed at arbitrary positions around the print volume, and the firmware will still work.

The values of anchor_A_z, anchor_B_z, and anchor_C_z describe the z-positions of the three normally lower placed anchors. These three values, as well as all the other anchor position values, can be changed mid-print, as evindenced by the widely covered 2017 tall tower print.

figure.figcaption: In this video from Apr 15, 2017, it's clear that the lines are terminated at different z-heights during different parts of the print.

post.p: All of these firmware features were being merged into the world's most used firmware at the time, called Marlin Firmware, in a public merge thread (similar to a forum thread) that was publicly available and open for anyone to read and participate in. This means Hangprinter and all its features were becoming an integrated and widely available type of 3d printer at the firmware level at the time before April 13, 2018.
post.h2: Why I Wrote This Prior Art Presentation
post.p: I think the patent in question is problematic because it's way too general, and covers well known and established knowledge. Nothing in the patent fulfills the criteria of being non-obvious to a person having ordinary skill in the art of cable driven robotics.
